results.title: The Restless eye: Eugene Delacroix: a film based on his paintings and his journals
results.creator_credit: Colin Nears, BBC and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Born in France in 1798 and dying in 1863, Eugene Delacroix was one of the most important Romantic painters of his time, earning him the retrospective reputation of, ‘a painter’s painter’ - his work’s being referenced and copied by the likes of Manet, Picasso and Van Gogh. This documentary is based on the journals that Delacroix wrote since age 24 which have since become literary classics in their own right. The writings reveal much of Delacroix’s dilemmas and intentions in his life and art. He was sceptical of progress, disdainful of the masses and scornful of revolution, but also intended to articulate his fascination with the barbarity and violence of ‘humanity’. Declaring, “I’m trying to make a beauty which is not quiet”, Delacroix painted a heady mix of beauty and cruelty with constant movement, colour, and restless energy. Cast includes John Carson as Delacroix.

results.title: Chillida
results.creator_credit: Laurence Boulting, William Leeson, ETB Euskal Telebista (Basque Television) and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This is a fine introduction to the work of renowned Basque sculptor Eduardo Chillida (born 1914), who works mainly with iron, clay, and stone to create both monumental and smaller works of art. Chillida’s art is primarily conceptual and not functional. We learn through his articulate commentary that Chillida is interested in space, time and the unknown. He begins the creative process without imposing preconceived thoughts, aims or ideas. Rather, Chillida seeks to break away from tradition, habit, expectation and repetition to discover and enter the unknown, the unseen. His approach is philosophical, and the result is impressive. The documentary also provides an overview of Chillida’s childhood, family background, his affinity with his hometown San Sebastian, and his working methods. The local history and traditions of his hometown are an important influence on his work as is its natural wonders. The abstract minimalism of Chillida’s art is spiritual, and a wondrous attempt to grapple with the mysteries and beauty of the world of nature.

results.title: Robert Motherwell and the New York school
results.creator_credit: Catherine Tatge, International Cultural Programming, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Robert Motherwell was the leading figure in the Abstract Expressionist movement in New York in the 1940’s and was to revolutionise the face of American painting. Made shortly before his death in 1991 this is director Tatge’s elegy to Motherwell, the vanguard of American modernism. Along with Arshille Gorky, William Bazeodis, Hans Hoffman, Franz Kline, William de Kooning, Barnett Newman, Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko and David Smith, Motherwell made up what is known as “The New York school”. The journey or search in their work as artists was to make art in the U.S. that was equal to that in Europe. Within a hostile political environment and known historically as the most hated of all the art movements, the Abstract Expressionists had achieved this by the early 1950’s. With archival footage and interviews this documentary paints an inspirational portrait of a man and movement in one of the most volatile times in modern history. Juxtaposed throughout is footage of Motherwell preparing for his retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum in New York.

results.title: Monsieur Rene Magritte
results.creator_credit: Adrian Maben, Neil Mundy, Antenne-2, RM Productions and WDR
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
About the life of Belgium artist Rene Magritte, one of the most famous of all surrealists. The documentary discusses his personal life and the motivations behind his art. Obsessed with the everyday, Magritte’s practise was to reinvent the ordinary by changing the ‘viewers’ perception. “It’s not the painting that changes your perception, it’s the thoughts triggered when looking at the work that does”. As a metaphysical painter like his mentor De Chirico, Magritte sought to make reality and meaning represented as visionary not literal - it’s this legacy that is explored in this documentary.

results.title: In search of pure colour: Pierre Bonnard 1867-1947
results.creator_credit: Didier Baussy, Antenne-2, Centre National D'Artes de Culture and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Pierre Bonnard was amongst one of the Nabi artists known to kick start French painting into modernism. Nick-named “The Japanese Nabi” for his predilection to things Japanese - exploring his love for line, colour and division of space, remained an inspiration throughout Bonnard’s life. Mostly working from his home overlooking Cannes, Bonnard spent his life in search of ‘pure colour’ wanting “to show what you see when you suddenly burst into a room”. This documentary describes Bonnard’s relationship with contemporary artists such as Gauguin, Matisse, Cezanne, Seurat and Renoir, his personal relationship with his models and his personal vision expressed through his paintings and sketchbooks. A life dedicated to ‘colour, form and reason’ over content and feeling.

results.title: Chanel, Chanel
results.creator_credit: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Narrated by Diana Quick and featuring a collage of fashion images, drawings and archive footage of the late Gabrielle Chanel herself, this is a fascinating documentary about an extraordinary woman and the house of fashion that she created. From her sportswear of the 1920’s through to the creation infamous Chanel suit in the 50’s, this film gives a broad overview of her life and examines the reasons why Chanel has become one of the greatest names in fashion. Also features interviews with Karl Lagerfeld.

results.title: The Story of fashion. Vol. 1: Remembrance of things past
results.creator_credit: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the first episode of this three part series, Karl Lagerfeld discusses the history of fashion from its rise in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries to the present day. Lagerfeld’s commentary, layered over a backdrop of fashion illustrations and archival footage, provides a broad survey of the evolution of this fascinating industry. The film begins by introducing the work of Charles Worth, inventor of haute couture and explores the changes of fashion over time to the work of some of the leading designers of today: Donna Karan; Fendi; Versace; Ralph Lauren; Valentino. Other areas that are discussed through interviews with leading industry players include dressmaking, fur, embroidery, hats, hairstyles, magazines and advertising techniques. Commentary written by Meredith Etherington-Smith and spoken by Diana Quick.

results.title: Vermeer: light, love and silence
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill, Malone Gill Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Written, produced, directed by Michael Gill and presented by Melvyn Bragg “Light, love and silence” focuses on the artist Jan Vermeer’s painting style and his intimate depictions of domestic interiors. Little known outside Holland for almost 200 years after his death, he is now considered one of the greatest painters of the seventeenth century. This documentary examines his paintings through detailed descriptions and discusses his technical skill, use of perspective and extraordinary understanding of light guided by the use of a camera obscura. Although very little is known about this intriguing artist for he left no letters, drawings or clues relating to the intention of his paintings, interviews with academics including Dr Jonathon Miller and Svetlana Alpers provide a greater insight into the social, political and scientific environment in which he worked.

results.title: Lucio Fontana: reaching out into space
results.creator_credit: Pierre Neel, Poorhouse Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The founder and major practitioner of the spatialist movement in art in the 1940s, Lucio Fontana, is the feature of this thorough and personal documentary which covers the expanse of his working career and his ongoing fascination with the concept and evolution of space in artistic practice. Through discussion of his major manifesto’s on the theory of spatialism and the range of work in multiple media through which he expressed his ideas and preoccupations, the program explores the notion of bringing real as opposed to illusory space into art and assesses Fontana’s achievement in the expression of this in the experimentation that marks his celebrated career. The program also traces his derivation of inspiration in creating art forms which are said to break out into space in the traditions of Baroque art and architecture as well as his influence on other artists of the same and subsequent periods. Through interviews with colleagues, friends, family and art critics, a profile of the artist emerges in both personal and artistic terms, with a celebration of the progression of his work and the importance of his impact on artistic expression for his multimedia experimentation, theoretical sophistication and professed feeling for humanity.

results.title: The Unquiet spirit: the life and art of Edgar Degas (1834-1917)
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Edgar Degas (1834-1917) was one the great French artists of the 19th Century. Often associated with the French impressionists, Degas set himself apart, preferring a studio practice studying human nature as opposed to ‘plain air’ paintings of landscape done by other impressionists of the time. This documentary examines the reputation and paradoxical personality of Degas in relation to society, his art career and life’s work and seeks to readdress this complex personality that too often was misrepresented during his lifetime. The sheer versatility and scope as an artist was not fully known until close to his death when a life’s worth of sculptures were revealed. Included throughout are examples of his drawings, paintings, prints and sculptures and picturesque views of France that serve to inform the atmosphere of Degas’s cultural environment. Obsessed with the great classical tradition it was Degas who took the study of the human figure towards modernism, able to articulate an intimacy of life that was both penetrating and shrewd. Written and narrated by David Thompson
